Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Unified Architecture for Learning of, and Reasoning with, Task Models: Theory and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal 0642882
"CAREER: A Unified Architecture for Learning of, and reasoning with, Task Models: Theory and Applications"
PI: Hector Munoz-Avila
Lehigh University

The focus of this project is the use of Hierarchical Task Networks (HTN) in planning. Humans learn complex skills by incrementally acquiring and combining simpler skills into skills of increasing complexity. Consequentially, many cognitive architectures use hierarchical models to represent relations between skills of different complexity. Over the years, the problem of automatically learning such hierarchical models has taken a backstage. Frequently, it is assumed that these models are given and research has instead concentrated on their use. This project drops this assumption and studies ways to learn the hierarchical models and use them for automated planning. The centerpiece of this project is a unified architecture for (1) learning hierarchical models from STRIPS plans and for (2) a multi-phase combination of lazy and eager learning using a common hierarchical task network (HTN) plan representation. Lazy learning produces hierarchical knowledge that directly represents the input examples. Eager learning produces hierarchical knowledge that generalizes multiple input examples. The unified architecture learns and plans with constructs whose generalization varies between these two extremes. The project also incorporates educational activities based on the multi-phase learning principles formulated in this work. This includes a pilot study, aimed at G6-12 students, to provide hands-on experience on introductory AI. Other broader impacts of this work include possible uses of HTN planning techniques in a wide range of potential applications that are amenable to hierarchical modeling, including project management for public events, software engineering project planning, and developing strategies for automated players in computer games.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we investigated and developed novel algorithms for automated learning of hierarchical or stratified planning domain knowledge. Akin to how many cognitive scientists believe humans learn,  our algorithms learn hierarchies in a bottom-up manner by analyzing the actions in the plans into hierarchies of increasing level of abstraction. Our algorithms can automatically learn this knowledge from a collection of plans (e.g., observations from activities performed by an agent). Our algorithms can also learn this hierarchical knowledge even in complex situations where actions have multiple alternative outcomes (e.g., arriving late or on-time). Furthermore, our algorithms can learn HTN domain descriptions that can be  used to rapidly yield high-quality plans.

There are significant benefits to society at large because of the potential applications of this research. Hierarchical planning has been used in a number of research and government institutions; applications include military planning, control of Unmanned Air Vehicles, strategy formulation in computer games, manufacturing processes, project management, and even automated story-telling.  However, the effort to encode the hierarchical  knowledge can be significant. Our research provides the means to automatically generate hierarchical  knowledge automatically.

For the educational component of the project, we modified a game environment to let K-12 students  experiment the effects of building knowledge bases without the need to learn complicated syntax. Our goal is to entice K-12 students to pursue IT careers.
